actualResults.title: X-XSS-Protection Header Explicitly Disabled (Set to 0)
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate security finding not in the expected list. The header X-XSS-Protection: 0 explicitly disables browser-based XSS protection. While related to XSS protection, this is a separate configuration issue from the reflected XSS vulnerability itself. This is a valid discovery that complements the main XSS finding.

actualResults.title: Missing Critical Security Headers (CSP, X-Frame-Options, HSTS, X-Content-Type-Options, Referrer-Policy)
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate security finding not in the expected list. The application lacks multiple critical security headers that provide defense-in-depth protection. While these headers could have helped mitigate the reflected XSS vulnerability through Content-Security-Policy, the missing headers represent a broader security misconfiguration issue affecting the entire application, not specific to XSS25.

actualResults.title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) Vulnerability - No CSRF Token Protection
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate security finding not in the expected list. The /xss25 endpoint accepts POST requests without CSRF token validation. While the endpoint is primarily a challenge/test endpoint, this demonstrates a systemic lack of CSRF protection that could affect other critical endpoints. This is a valid new discovery related to the same endpoint but representing a different vulnerability class.

actualResults.title: Information Disclosure Through Error Messages
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate security finding not in the expected list. The application returns detailed error messages revealing backend implementation details (JavaScript/Node.js, dynamic property manipulation, possible eval() usage). While information disclosure, this is a separate issue from the reflected XSS vulnerability and represents a valid discovery of a different vulnerability type.

actualResults.title: Outdated and Vulnerable Werkzeug Version (1.0.1) with Version Disclosure
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate security finding not in the expected list. The application is running end-of-life versions of Werkzeug (1.0.1) and Python (2.7.18), with version information disclosed in HTTP headers. This represents a separate vulnerability class (vulnerable dependencies and version disclosure) that is application-wide rather than specific to the XSS25 endpoint. This is a valid new discovery.

matched.expectedTitle: Reflected XSS via Blacklist Bypass in XSS25
matched.actualTitle: Reflected XSS in Solution Parameter (XSS25 Challenge Endpoint) + Reflected XSS via 'solution' POST Parameter with onfocus Event Handler Bypass
matched.matchReason: Both expected and actual findings identify the same core vulnerability: a blacklist-based filter that blocks keywords like 'script', 'onerror', 'onclick', 'onload', 'onmouseover', and 'svg', but fails to block 'onfocus' and other event handlers. The actual findings provide multiple confirmed payloads demonstrating successful XSS bypass: , ,
